title: Understanding Scientific Notation
text: Scientific notation is used to express very large or small numbers in a concise form. It is written as the product of a number (usually between $$1$$ and 10) and a power of $$10$$.

title: Defining the Components
text: In the notation $$-3.9{10}^{-13}$$, the number $$-3.9$$ is called the coefficient, and $${10}^{-13}$$ is the power of ten. Together, they help express a very small number.

title: Interpreting the Exponent
text: The exponent in the scientific notation, like $$-13$$ in $${10}^{-13}$$, tells us how many spaces to move the decimal point to convert it to standard form. A negative exponent indicates we move the decimal to the left.

title: Moving the Decimal
text: Starting with the coefficient $$-3.9$$, move the decimal point $$13$$ places to the left because the exponent is $$-13$$. Each move represents multiplying the coefficient by $$0.1$$.

title: Managing the Decimal Place
text: Count how many zeros will appear before any non-zero digits when moving the decimal from $$3.9$$ to the left by $$13$$ places.

title: Expressing the Number
text: Now, write the number in standard notation by placing the decimal after the $$12$$ zeros as $$-0.00000000000039$$.
